pros: Loved it, great community to work in.
cons: None, it was all good.

review_title: The best edtech company, hands down
pros:
+ Education is an amazing space to work in, you feel good about everything you work on
+ Massive scale of impact - over 10% of US K12 students use Clever every day (and growing)
+ Very thoughtful and intentional culture - everything from the culture tenants to seating arrangements to the order of entrees in the lunch line is thoughtfully done to do best by employees
+ Everyone who's here is here to help improve education, and show it by being super collaborative and putting aside ego for the greater good.
cons: - Education isn't a hyper-growth industry, and although Clever is one of the most successful edtech companies ever, it's not doubling in size every 6 months like a scooter rental company. That means you're less likely to skyrocket in title, and you'll spend more time developing expertise in your current role.

review_title: One of the best company cultures and professional development experiences
pros:
the 3 founders haven't sold out
foster a great work environment, lots of company events
social outreach programs and positive impact in our community
fantastic perks and benefits
plenty of opportunities to grow at a ed-tech company
open PTO
A-grade hiring
safe rides program
management cares about personal development
cons: 8th and mission in sf isn't a great block, safety is a concern, but Clever covers that with their safe rides program and a secure building.
advice_to_mgmt: I've worked at a couple start-ups in the Bay Area, and Clever is definitely one of the more fun and organized ones out there. As an engineer, documentation and collaboration is key, and Clever does this well. There is a real sense of togetherness, respect and gratitude around Clever. Keep up the good work!

review_title: Mission driven, people focused, fun and innovative!
pros:
+ Typical start-up perks -- catered lunch every day, unlimited snacks, open floor plan
+ Good benefits including a professional development budget, unlimited Amazon learning credits, health & wellness activities, unlimited PTO, and much more
+ Culture and community is a very important element of Clever's foundation

Everyone here is united around a mission of improving the K-12 education experience; but more importantly, I love coming to work every day knowing that I am surrounded by people who support my growth and care about me personally.
cons:
- No 401k employee match
- Neighborhood is not the best
- Room for growth in terms of promotional movement within the company
- Very young company, (we're making strides in hiring more experienced leaders)
advice_to_mgmt: I'd like to see more women and people of color in the executive positions.

review_title: Great company with even better people
pros:
Clever is very intentional about helping employees to grow. I've learned a lot in my position and have been provided with many opportunities to take on projects that interest me. The managers of the Customer Solutions team have worked to build out "career pathways" that help people on our team to grow vertically within the team by spearheading new and interesting projects or to grow laterally by eventually moving other teams.

The best part about Clever is the people! Everyone is incredibly nice and there's a good culture built around inclusion. People at Clever genuinely care about the mission and helping to improve the education space.

Also—free lunch every day :)
cons: Back to school season is a very busy time that requires a lot of time and dedication for about 9 weeks of the year.

pros:
+ Helping bring technology to classroom learning is very fulfilling
+ Working with smart people who are passionate about what they do and want to make things better each day
+ Camp Clever - three days of professional learning and team bonding in a beautiful outdoor environment
+ Free lunches, lots of celebrations and recognition of accomplishments
+ Beautiful office environment
+ Unlimited vacation time
cons: - Not that flexible on remote working

pros:
-strongest culture of any organization I have worked for. Clever has a culture of learning, innovation, and social connection to education and our mission.
-excellent strategic vision as a company - I feel very confident in Clever's future
-benefit of working for a company that is in more than 60% of schools gives me the ability to get a macro-level view of education at scale in the US
-great executive team and leadership - they balance rigor for standards & care for employees extremely well. They are great role models
-excellent work-life balance
cons: -like many fast-paced start-ups in the Bay, we could benefit from improving our retention levels of younger employees, and should continue to build strong career pathways in all departments
advice_to_mgmt: -Keep up the transparency, rigor, and investment in your people! These efforts have really paid off and made Clever an incredible place to work.

review_title: Working to change education in an engaging/fun work environment
pros:
-Startup environment - opportunity wherever you seek it to gain new skills and find new ways to add value
-Flat org structure with abundant opportunities to take ownership in your role and solve interesting problems
-Leadership listens openly to feedback has taken substantive measures to create structures for career growth/support
-Working on a product that improves the way public schools operate
-Transparent organization that works to keep employees in the loop on strategic decisions
-Founders and leadership embody the org's cultural tenants
-Friendly work environment - weekly happy hour and team members frequently socialize outside of work
-Product teams work closely with customer facing teams to improve product and services
cons:
-Some lack of structure in workflows due to pace of work and high level of cross-team collaboration
- Some lack of experience due to high growth and young teams (but also means lots of opportunity)
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to foster a collaborative environment that values doing the extra credit, asking good tough questions, and keep recognizing valuable work and contributions from individuals regardless of rank.

review_title: A Great Place for the Mission Oriented
pros: The people and culture are absolutely fantastic. It's a treat to come to work every day to be surrounded by such smart people. Senior management strongly believes in transparency, which makes expectation setting so much easier. I and others on my team have also been given numerous opportunities to explore other parts of the company which has been super exciting. Overall, it's by far the best place I've worked.
cons: Sometimes things feel a little bit clicky, but as more time has passed in my role, those walls start to come down. 401k doesn't have matching (which is understandable for a start-up). Movement between different level is confusing and I honestly couldn't tell you what I need to do to get a promotion.
advice_to_mgmt: Make paths promotions more clear to ICs and keep up the great work!

pros:
-The company is solving really hard problems in K12 EdTech, and it's really exciting to be part of the movement
-Incredible coworkers with the largest hearts. Everyone brings their full selves to work which means we work hard and are also all friends
-It's easy to speak directly with any of our executives through slack, coffee chats...etc.
-Clever loves humor - nothing gets the office going like the latest custom gif. The silliness makes the workplace really fun
cons: -Like other startups, we could always use for headcount/resources

pros: Clever attracts incredibly passionate, smart, and mission-driven talent. Great career growth opportunities for high performers, and individuals are able to influence the company's direction. The company has grown to make a big impact in K12 education and continues to work on exciting problems.
cons: Small company with a fairly young workforce, so we don't have as many experienced leaders to learn from. Leadership could fight harder to retain valuable employees and reduce turnover. The office location isn't ideal but it's not unsafe.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue focusing energy on filling the open executive roles with amazing, experienced leaders.

pros:
Smart, passionate people.
Meaningful work.
Fun work culture.
Great yearly company offsite called Camp Clever.

As an onboarding engineer for the first 2 months you get to rotate through a selection of the teams and get a taste of what they're working on.

Awesome "always a student" culture, embracing learning and teaching every day.

Tech debt is relatively low and manageable with a micro service architecture.

Cross-functional team collaboration is great, and there are opportunities to explore and learn more about e.g. product management or design if that interests you.

As a relatively small company still, the org structure is pretty flat and everyone really approachable - so you can regularly find yourself sitting down eating a relaxed lunch next to the executive team members.
cons: Immediate vicinity outside the office can be off-putting.

review_title: Awesome group of passionate people changing education for the better
pros:
+ Amazing engineering team with a strong culture of learning + teaching
+ Great stack: React/Redux, Node, Golang
+ A focus on developing engineers and giving them tasks that they're interested in
+ Good variety of work: ETL pipeline, analytics pipelines, AWS/infrastructure, and of course frontend web apps
cons:
- At time of writing, we have about 35 engineers, so occasionally a lot of responsibility falls on a single individual
- Currently without a VP of engineering
advice_to_mgmt: Continue our focus on making the end-user's experience a delightful one, and let's avoid product bloat as we mature!

review_title: Great culture and a great place for growth
pros: Clever is full of great people all working together to improve education. To be at a place where everyone is so focused on making an impact together is amazing. There is a great culture here that really allows for a lot of interaction with teams outside of your own and you're encouraged to get to know your co-workers as people and care for them. It is a company that is devoted to investing in your growth as a person and a professional and is always seeking to provide the support you feel you need. There is also a lot of space created for you to enact change and you always work on high impact tasks; there is no busy work.
cons: It is a small company that is still trying to capitalize on the rapidly growing user base so there can be some thrash with products and here and there. The office is not in the best part of SF and as a company we can tend to be a bit meeting heavy in comparison to a typical engineering environment.

pros:
Collaborative culture and kind people
Amazing product that is changing the way edtech is used in schools
Good perks
cons: Young workforce, many are new in career.

pros: Great product. Efficient, easy to use, and overall brings great values to educators. VERY cool work atmosphere. The building itself is awesome, with free food and drinks. The culture is young and fun. Many employees are former educators, which makes for a productive and passionate environment. GREAT benefits.
cons: SO much movement, which is to expected at such a small company. They hire low and promise growth, but compensation does not come with the growth. Many feel underpaid and overworked. Although leadership pats themselves on the back for transparency, many feel it's lacking. People are thrown into management roles with very little experience. Although it's a great growth opportunity for the new managers, it makes other members of the team feel uneasy.
advice_to_mgmt: Fight for better compensation for your team, push back at leadership, try to ease into transition, continue giving great feedback, keep up the fun times, and listen to your employees.

pros: Easy to communicate with teammates and the management.
cons: The position was temporary but otherwise, not a bad experience.

review_title: Great people, good product, high turnover, iffy management
pros: Lots of intelligent, fun, friendly and passionate people, more diverse than your average tech company, school districts are grateful for product, small enough company that you can influence decisions and have an impact, catered lunch
cons: High turnover, high/stressful workloads (which leads to burnout), inexperienced middle management (which leads to a slough of issues), politics, lack of diversity in leadership, stingy compensation decisions, lack of career and skill development opportunities, changing expectations and goals can lead to confusion
advice_to_mgmt: Invest in better management and general training, keep working on feedback and communication norms throughout the company, work on making sure employee expectations coming from middle management are clear and that people take accountability for mistakes. Keep working on the retention issue. Pay more attention to moderating workloads and curbing burnout, because it was a big problem in 2018. Invest more in young talent and career development. Pay people better, especially when they are working their butts off

pros: Pay, food, people.. opportunity to advance.
cons: Alot of change because it's a little company.
advice_to_mgmt: None keep it up

pros:
At Clever, you get to work on an important problem in society, and it's validating to hear from teachers, students, and administrators who love the product.

Many of the team are former educators, and people are honest and good.

Perks are solid, lots of opportunities to bond with teammates.

The company does appear to want to address attrition issues genuinely, and recent executive hires are promising.
cons:
There's been a lot of turnover; the goals (and the goal-setting process) change a lot. Decisions, especially around compensation, can feel needlessly stingy.

Feedback culture has been a long-term work-in-progress; there often isn't honesty around mistakes that were made and ways that the company or teams can improve.

Many managers are in the job for the first time and there seem to be weak lines of communication from employees to those up top.
advice_to_mgmt: Set better examples of good feedback. Recognize individuals more meaningfully. Reflect explicitly on missed goals. Involve employees more in company-wide decisions and issues.

pros:
- Culture driven
- Mission driven
- Camp Clever
cons:
- Low pay
- Raises are rare and small when they happen
- Company direction changes quarter to quarter
- Flat growth

pros: Great environment. Family oriented Great hours
cons: Growth is slim to none.
advice_to_mgmt: Need more growth to keep the place very happy

pros:
+ The people here are some of the best people you will ever work with. Hands down. I love coming to work every day!
+ The problems we're working on are problems that will have a real, tangible impact should we be successful. There's meaning to working here.
+ If you want to do something, there's not a lot getting in the way of you doing that thing. Clever rewards those who notice a problem and take the initiative of solving it, which leads to a true culture of empowerment.
+ We're a respected name in the industry, and we have the ability to really affect the future of edtech
+ Great benefits and plenty of opportunities to wind down/socialize with your colleagues, if you're into that sort of thing
cons:
- We're a young company (in terms of average age), as is the case with most SF tech startups. Because of this we sometimes can get pushed into prioritizing things that aren't important in the long view, and sometimes we give weight to things that really do not need to become company-wide discussions. People tend to over-share more than you would find in your average professional environment, and we skew towards seriously entertaining more fringe opinions than is productive sometimes.
- We're still figuring out our long-term direction. We know the larger problem we want to solve, but the road of how to get there isn't quite figured out yet. The plus side is that everyone here is really empowered to try to work this out together!
- Having a double-sided market (Our "customers" are both school districts and learning applications, though only one directly affects revenue commitments) complicates a lot of our business decisions and sometimes even internally we're not clear on what customers we're serving.
- Even though overall many employees are young and only a few years into their careers, many seem to think they should become a manager after a year or so. It's difficult when many people at the company are thinking about their next role at the company rather than the one they already have!
advice_to_mgmt: Think about the long-term vision of Clever more specifically. What can we do now to set that up for tomorrow? The growth we're currently having is unsustainable if we don't start building for the future iterations of Clever.

pros:
I was with Clever for a little over a year and I have so many positive things to say...

-For a relatively small-ish startup, Clever has their culture nailed down. People live and breathe what they refer to as "Culture Tenants", which all have to do with the theme of "education and learning".
-Hiring former teachers or folks who have been in academia has really helped in creating end-user empathy.
-One of the few companies where I have seen different functions treat each other as equals. It is rare to see, for example, customer solutions and engineering just hang out and get to know each other.
-Awesome opportunities to grow. If you know your stuff, all you have to do is raise your hand and jump in. So many people started as entry-level customer solutions teams and moved into different roles within the team (sales, product, and even partner engineering!). Here, titles don't matter. The hard work you do does.
-There is a strong commitment to diversity and inclusion. People here genuinely care about making a difference in the world, starting with the workplace.
cons:
-Immaturity- because many employees are early-in-career, sometimes, issues that are brought up can feel a little silly and childish at times and yet they are still entertained.
-Office politics- sometimes it felt like "Game of Thrones".
-Lots of feels- a lot of emotions and feelings to handle...far more so than what is appropriate behavior in the workplace. It felt a little bit like "The Real World" at times.
-Way too much time spending "chit chatting". People use the internal communication tool for things that are really not productive. If you are not someone who is like that, it can be difficult to disconnect.
advice_to_mgmt: Work on raising the maturity levels of teams by setting a solid example and rewarding people who put their heads down and work rather than spend time playing politics, gossiping and creating noise. Reduce the number of extra-curricular activities so that people can understand that they are here to work and not just be entertained. Reduce the entitled behavior and don't entertain unprofessional behavior from even your best people.

pros: Energetic atmosphere with coworkers who are sharp and driven.
cons: Few professional development opportunities and internal paths for career advancement.

review_title: Great company on a great mission
pros: Energetic, passionate team working to solve a worthwhile problem. Intellectually challenging, a fun culture, and impressive executive leadership team. It's great to work at a company that prizes learning and improvement in everything we do.
cons: There are some of the normal growing pains of a quickly growing company and those have their drawbacks at times.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue developing pathways for people to grow internally at Clever, take on new roles and challenges, and contribute in lots of ways across the company.

review_title: Doing Great Things in Ed Tech
pros:
-Great Perks: Lunch, snacks, happy hour, unlimited PTO
-Transparent, open-door leadership
-Honest discussion of company performance every Friday--we celebrate successes and discuss shortcomings.
-Direct impact on classrooms and kids
-Great, mission driven people
-Did I mention the people? Everyone is genuinely interesting and easy to talk to.
-Steadily gaining women in leadership positions- half the VP-level team is female.
-The team is on a huge diversity push-- quantitative company-wide metrics based on hires and the team make-up.
-A qualitative metric I've heard tossed around is "Our team demographics should look the demographics of our customers-- we want to be sure we can represent kids from every background"
-Start-up perks with zero tech-bro vibe. Lots of former teachers.
-Close to public transit
cons: -Some growing pains... going from unknown to almost half of US schools in 3 years meant rapid expansion. We're still filling in some holes in the team.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work everyone!

pros: Amazing coworkers, smart ideas, transparency and flexibility to shift when needed to be most effective.
cons: Growth challenges similar to most startups, young company, young leaders.

review_title: Making huge impact by solving hard problems
pros: Working alongside very intelligent people to solve both hard technical problems and a larger problem impeding education today. Very motivating to hear feedback from schools or applications that we're helping students learn. Incredibly genuine and unique culture that values continued learning and individuality.
cons: Growing pains inherent in many startups: too much we want to do and not enough people to do it.

review_title: Passion makes this an exceptional place to work
pros:
+The people really make Clever-- hiring is taken really seriously to make sure we're getting people who are excited about the mission, the role, our culture... It's a diverse crew, but we all share a passion for our jobs. I am always happy about going to work.
+Benefits and perks are great, competitive even in SF
+ Start-up vibe means everyone is willing to jump in all the time; great to see things really getting done vs. a company where small changes seem to take forever to go through the right channels
+ Everyone is encouraged to question the company, certain decisions, industry norms.... it's refreshing!
+ Did I mention how great the people are?
cons:
- start up = limited room for actual career dev/promotions-- you'll grow a crazy amount, but it might not be reflected on a resume
- Sometimes wearing a hat for too long means that job accidentally becomes yours-- working here means learning to balance "sure I'll help!" and "maybe there is a better solution."
advice_to_mgmt:
> As we grow, consider providing more space for career development
> Be sure to balance benefits and appreciation so it doesn't skew towards the engineers!

review_title: A passionate, super-smart community that's working hard to solve a real problem in education
pros:
I've watched as Clever has grown from ~10 to ~50 people over the past couple of years. Here are the things I love:
- Smart, dependable coworkers
- Everybody's united under a common mission to improve education (it never feels like it's about the money, but being for-profit avoids a lot of the inefficiencies and frustrations of non-profit work)
- I have very close friends at work and we do fun things together, but it doesn't feel insular like many other large tech companies' social networks
- We have a culture of learning, and one in which all ideas can be challenged by anyone
cons: We've been growing really fast. It's hard to preserve culture and scale processes. We also haven't really figured out what advancement looks like yet - right now everybody is more focused on the problems we're solving than on career growth for employees.
advice_to_mgmt: As we continue to grow, I think we'll need to apply the same focus to our employees' personal growth that we have to the problem we're solving.

review_title: Thoughtful, rapidly growing startup that’s helping kids use educational software
pros:
-Strong commitment to the education mission, from the founders down to individual employees. Everyone knows why they’re here, and many people have in-class teaching experience.

-Extremely thoughtful approach to culture that focuses on both maintaining what we have and ensuring that we don’t just hire people in the same mold.

-Focus on learning new things, which is apparent everywhere from company benefits (free Amazon credits for learning materials) to events (biweekly “tech” talks on individual employees’ interests like exoplanets, mashup DJing, and history)

-Feels like working around your friends - everyone is cool and interesting in addition to being capable, and people voluntarily hang out after work all the time.

-Blame-free culture, both within and outside engineering; I’ve been really impressed with the way we’ve dealt with outages and failures.

-Real-time rapid growth - in the 10 months that I’ve been here, we’ve almost doubled in school count and the number of students on the platform (now at 30K schools and 13M students).
cons: -We’re growing pretty rapidly, and we’re about to outgrow our office. We have plans to move within the city in the near term but in the interim it's going to be pretty cramped and noisy. We’re exploring creative interim solutions, though (WeWork spaces, renting an offsite house, etc.).

pros:
+ Everyone here really believes in the mission / company and wants to make schools a better place. It's refreshing to see people who actually care about the mission rather than people who believe in the concept of a good mission. It makes for a really positive collaborative environment.
+ Equally as iterative on processes for product development as well as people operations. Super lightweight agile dev environment. Clever actually takes feedback into account when deciding benefits, feedback processes, and company operations.
+ People really care about each other and want their peers to succeed. Because everyone's interested in learning and improving, we're able to keep moving forward and getting stuff done in a non-competitive environment.
cons: - As engineers, we tend to get excited about the latest and greatest technologies. Sometimes I feel like we're using more tools and services than is necessary. I'm mixed on this one, while I can see the benefits to both sides, I'd personally prefer if we could consolidate so there's less of a learning curve when switching teams or taking up a new project.
advice_to_mgmt: Maintain your honesty and transparency as we grow.

review_title: Warm, dynamic company that is solving a real problem for real teachers
pros:
Very strong commitment to a positive company culture and values, driven and capable people working as a tight-knit team. Often feels like more of a family when hanging out with each other.
- very transparent management, no question is off the table
- using the latest tech (Docker, Go, etc), not afraid of change
- constant learning for all employees
- very flexible work hours, where work done is what counts
- in times of high-stress, people are very calm and trust each other to make the right judgement calls
- company is highly respected by both Silicon Valley and the education world (reformers *and* establishment)
- all parts of the company work together with mutual respect - no divide between engineering and sales, for instance
- a culture of appreciation, not the toxic mercenary / entitled culture common in SV/SF
cons:
There are a few growing pains: we spend a lot of time hiring and the engineering team could really use the leadership that a VP Engineering would bring. (although the founders are hard at work looking for the right person)
Mentorship could also be stronger - it feels as though everyone is working hard enough that there's little slack to work on skills with others.
advice_to_mgmt: As we get larger, it's going to be very tough to preserve the small things that make working at Clever really enjoyable. Perhaps we could have a day every month set aside to brainstorm or implement ideas on additions to the culture, or to 'ride-along' with someone from a different part of the organization so that we keep the mutual understanding between teams.

review_title: Smart & creative team making a difference in education
pros:
Mission-driven organization that actually makes a difference in the lives of students and teachers.
Really smart, collaborative, thoughtful, enthusiastic, and funky team that I genuinely enjoy problem-solving, karaoke-ing, and hanging out with
Transparent leadership
Lots of autonomy for employees
cons: Lots of open roles means that lots of people are doing more than just their role (good for understanding what's going on across the org, but can be hard for prioritization)

pros: Strong sense of purpose. The dedication to their mission is admirable. Product is solid and culture is compassionate and pervasive.
cons: Turnover is high. Leadership is not aligned on vision and inconsistent quarter to quarter. No clear vision of long term success as market adapts to their first mover advantage.

pros: great place to be, nice ppl around
cons: hours are really bad, and sometimes unreasinabe
advice_to_mgmt: pay more attention on work life balance
